Department of Chemical Engineering, King Fahd University of Petroleum and Minerals Dhahran Saudi Arabia Catalytic cracking of naphtha to produce olefins using ZSM-5 can fulfill the growing demand for light olefins and the energy problem. In the current work, vanadium oxide in different supports was mixed with ZSM-5 as a tandem catalyst for oxidative cracking of n-hexane to light olefins. The results showed that adding vanadium as a tandem catalyst with ZSM-5 increased n-hexane conversion to 68.8 % for VOx/Al2O3 and 86.7 % for VOx/SiO2 addition. Selectivity to light olefin was significantly changed due to the oxidative dehydrogenation reaction in the vanadium active site. The position and proximity of the metal oxide and acid sites determine the reaction pathway and product distribution. A stability test showed that the conversion of n-hexane decreased from 58 % to 37 %. Still, the selectivity to olefin was stable at 60 % due to the carbon formation blocking the acid site, not the metal oxide sites. Graphical Abstract Keywords Catalytic cracking Naphtha Olefin, Tandem catalyst ZSM-5, Vanadium Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Light olefins, particularly propylene, are of growing significance due to their important role in the chemical industry [1,2]. Ethylene and propylene are produced from thermal steam-cracking gas oil, light alkane, and naphtha. Among other feedstock, light naphtha is one of the most plentiful and inexpensive raw materials in Saudi Arabia due to becoming an undesirable gasoline blending component [1]. Light naphtha has low cracking reactivity because the necessary Carbenium ion is more challenging to generate [3]. However, naphtha may typically be converted significantly, even under very moderate conditions, over a new zeolite catalyst due to its high acidity in the fresh catalyst [4]. Zeolite Socony Mobil–5 (ZSM-5) type is preferable because it is highly reactive and selective toward light olefins. Compared to steam cracking, catalytic cracking of light naphtha over an acid catalyst is an excellent approach to light olefin production regarding product distribution, especially propylene to ethylene ratio and saving energy usage [5]. Much research has been done to improve the activity of the catalyst and selectivity to olefin by adjusting the acidity [6], smaller crystal size [7], modifying the pore structure [8], and promoting metal [9]. Catalytic cracking of light naphtha using zeolite produces light alkane (ethane, propane, and butane) as a byproduct. There are methods for increasing the selectivity of light naphtha to olefin, such as dehydrogenation and oxidative cracking. Light alkane byproducts are potentially converted into light olefin (ethylene, propylene, and butylene) by dehydrogenation reaction using metal or oxide. Putting metal or oxide in zeolite will have two active sites: acid surface for catalytic cracking and metal or oxide as an active site for dehydrogenation reaction to increase selectivity to olefin. Another method is oxidative cracking, employing an oxidant agent or using lattice oxygen in a metal oxide catalyst [10]. An oxidant flowed to the cracking reaction, which improved naphtha reactant conversion; however, this would result in excessive oxidative cracking. To address the issue of excessive oxidation, the oxidant gas was substituted with the metal oxide, resulting in the catalytic cracking of naphtha triggered by lattice oxygen. Coke formation can be reduced with oxygen as a reactant during a cracking reaction. Furthermore, the oxidative cracking reaction may be run at lower temperatures than conventional olefin synthesis methods [11]. Several variably supported vanadium catalysts have been studied as a source of lattice oxygen in oxidative dehydrogenation. Aside from the promoting effects, the support's acid-based nature influences the vanadium-based catalyst's activity. This is caused by feed and product adsorption and desorption on the acid-base sites. On acidic supports, basic reactant adsorption and product desorption are well-recognized [12]. Alumina's excellent features, such as its high hydrothermal stability, strong mechanical strength, large surface area, and homogeneous pore size distribution, make it suitable as a support for oxidative reaction catalyst [13,14]. On the other hand, alumina's acidic nature may produce hydrocarbon over-cracking, resulting in more light hydrocarbon products and carbon formation. Furthermore, the strong interaction between vanadium and alumina produces considerable metal oxide surface dispersion, favoring deep oxidation processes [15]. The applications of mesoporous SiO2-supported vanadium oxide in propane conversion have received much interest in recent years [16,17]. Meanwhile, Vanadium oxides supported on Al2O3 performed better regarding nonoxidative butane dehydrogenation [18,19]. This work investigated the role of VOx during the catalytic cracking reaction and the effects of VOx/Al2O3 and VOx/SiO2 addition on the initial reactions of n-hexane over H-ZSM-5 catalysts. N-hexane is used as a model compound for light naphtha because, ideally, n-hexane can be maximized for propylene production by following this reaction route C6 → 2 C3= , if we can control the cracking of C-C. Its goal is to validate the dehydrogenation reaction in the n-hexane cracking reaction, the proximity of both active sites, elucidate its effects on the reactions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis A new ZSM-5 catalyst with a Si/Al mole ratio of 50 was purchased from a commercial Alfa Aesar. Ammonium-ZSM-5 was calcined for five h at 550 °C in a furnace to get protonated H-ZSM-5, which is used as a parent catalyst (H-ZSM-5). The Incipient Wet Impregnation (IWI) technique, as shown in Fig. S1, was used to incorporate VOx into the ZSM-5. Vanadium precursor was purchased from a commercial Sigma-Aldrich. The vanadium impregnation was kept constant at 10 % (equal to 0.52 g NH4VO3 for every 1 g of zeolite). To load vanadium, the needed amount of vanadium metavanadate was dissolved in ethanol, and the solution was dropped over the Zeolite under vacuum conditions in a conical flask. The paste was forcefully stirred with a magnetic stirrer until a consistent color was seen. The resultant mixture dried at room temperature. Then, all the prepared catalysts were calcined for 5 hours at 550 °C with a ramping rate of 2 °C/min, and this catalyst was denoted as VOx/ZSM-5. IWI procedure was also applied with γ-Al2O3 and SiO2 to support vanadium loading with the same percentage of 10 %. γ-Al2O3 support synthesized from the previous study by surfactant-free method [20]. Synthesized catalyst VOx/Al2O3 was physically mixed using a mortar with parent zeolite (H-ZSM-5) with the weight ratio 1:1 to get VOx/Al 2 O 3 -ZSM-5 catalyst. VOx/SiO2 was also combined with H-ZSM-5 and denoted as VOx/SiO 2 -ZSM-5 catalyst with the same weight ratio. Fig. 1 shows the physical mixing procedure and treatment after the mixing. After mixing, the samples were dried overnight at 100 °C and calcined for 5 h at 550 °C with a ramping rate of 2 °C/min in a furnace. 2.2 Catalyst characterization 2.2.1 X-ray diffraction (XRD) The physical phase of the catalysts was determined Using a Rigaku MiniFlex II benchtop XRD, and the crystallinity of the prepared catalysts was investigated. The measurements were taken with a 2°/min scan rate between two 5–65° ranges and an increment of 0.01 at 20 mA, 0.15406 nm, and 40 kV. In the catalyst's XRD pattern, diffraction lines attributed to ZSM-5 zeolite, SiO2, and Al2O3 support were discovered. 2.2.2 N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms Nitrogen adsorption isotherm analysis determined the synthesized catalysts' specific surface area and pore size distribution. A Micromeritics 2920 chemisorption analyzer was used to create nitrogen isotherms. Before analysis, a 0.2 g solid sample was degassed at 350; °C for 3 h to eliminate impurities and residual solvents. The nitrogen adsorption isotherms were measured at 77 K across a pressure range of 106-1. 2.2.3 Hydrogen-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) The reduction behavior of vanadium oxide species was investigated using TPR in chemisorption Autochem II 2920 micromeritics unit under the following conditions: 50 ml/min of 5 % H2 in Ar, the heating rate of 10 °C/min to a final temperature of 900 °C. The molecular sieve 4 A removed the water produced during the TPR before passing through the thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The peak region of the hydrogen consumption figure was calibrated with argon pulses injected into the TPR gas flow. 2.2.4 Ammonia-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) The acid characteristics were investigated using an NH3 temperature-programmed-desorption (TPD) to check weak, strong, and total acidity. Using a Micromeritics chemisorption 2920 analyzer. For analysis, 50 mg of material was placed into the sample tube and degassed under Helium flow at 300 °C. Following degassing, the catalyst samples were returned to ambient temperature, and an ammonia gas mixture with helium comprising 5 % of ammonia saturated the catalyst's surface. After being saturated with ammonia, the system was cleaned with inert gas to eliminate any remaining probe molecules. The NH3-TPD heating rate is ten °C/min from room temperature to 600 °C. A calibrated thermal conductivity detector (TCD) measures the desorbed ammonia. Bronsted and Lewis's acidity was measured using a pyridine adsorption/desorption experiment using FTIR Thermo Fisher equipment. In every experiment, 0.8 g KBr standard was mixed with 6 mg zeolite. The IR band was recorded and measured within the 1400–2000 cm−1 range. 2.2.5 Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) The prepared catalysts' morphology and elemental characteristics were analyzed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The catalyst samples were coated with gold to remove the charge, improve contrast, and improve visibility. The microscope was correctly focused to produce crisp pictures. During the study, the sample was fired by an electron beam to create backscattered electrons. These dispersed electrons were collected and analyzed to generate photographs to determine the morphology and elemental compositions of the samples. 2.2.6 Raman spectroscopy The molecular structure of the produced catalyst was identified using a Thermo Scientific DXR3 Raman spectrometer. For each analysis, about 0.1 g of the material was dehydrated with dry air at 550°C for one hour before cooling to room temperature. The sample was placed in the quartz sample holder before the spectra was recorded. A 532 nm ion laser was used to excite the catalyst sample throughout the analysis, and spectrograms in the 200–1200 cm−1 range were obtained. 2.2.7 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy was utilized to investigate the surface characteristics of freshly synthesized catalysts. XPS offers critical information on metal oxides' binding energy, oxidation state, and reducibility. The XPS studies were done utilizing an ESCALAB 250Xi photoelectron spectrometer microprobe equipped with an Al Kα anode for sample excitation (1 eV = 1.6302 × 10−19 joules and hѵ =1.4866 × 103), a 120 W X-ray source, and a 180° double focusing hemispherical energy analyzer. The data was processed with Advantage software. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation Experiments on n-hexane catalytic cracking were conducted in a CREC Riser Simulator fluidized bed under gas-phase conditions without oxygen. The main body of the CREC Riser Simulator is seen in Fig. 2. The CREC Riser Simulator's technical specifications can be obtained elsewhere [21]. A 0.1–0.2 g catalyst was loaded into the CREC riser simulator reactor for the experiment. The reactor was heated to the desired reaction temperature (550 °C). Inert Argon gas flowed to the reactor to check the leak and ensure the absence of oxygen gas. When the reactor achieves the reaction temperature, turn on the vacuum pump to evacuate the pressure until it reaches 21 kPa (4 psi). The reactor and the vacuum box preserved the pressure by closing the valve in a six-port isolation. Turned on the high-speed impeller in the riser simulator and fluidized the catalysts. At 4000 rpm, 20 μL n-hexane was fed into the reactor with a syringe, allowing the reaction to run for 5–20 s. When the reaction is finished, open the valve by pressing the six-port isolation button and instantly transferring the gas products from the reactor into the vacuum box. A gas chromatography online Agilent 7890 with TCD ((6Ft 1/8 2 mm HayeSep Q 80/100 Ni) detected the permanent gases such as H2, CO, CH4, and CO2) and FID columns (HP AL/S (8 μm) 25 m × 0.32 mm) detects CH4 and other hydrocarbons [16]. N-hexane conversion and product selectivity can be calculated from the GC data using Eqs. (1) and (2), respectively. (1) X C 6 H 14 % = ∑ j z j n j 6 n 6 + ∑ j z j n j x 100 (2) S j % = z j n j ∑ j z j n j x 100 Where n-hexane conversion is noted as X C 6 H 14 (%), unconverted n-hexane moles is denoted as n 6 , The number of carbon atoms of component j is noted as z j , The number of carbons of component j is noted as n j 3 Results and discussion 3.1 X-ray diffraction (XRD) Fig. 3 depicts the powder X-ray diffraction (XRD)patterns of ZSM-5 and its modification. The prepared materials show the typical XRD spectra of the typical ZSM-5, with peaks at 2θ = 7.9°, 9.04°, 13.59°, 14.19°, 15.14°, 15.91°, 23.38°, 24.16°, 25.63°, and 30.18°, which correspond to the planes (101), (111), (102), (112), (131), (022), (051), (313), (323), and (062). The diffraction peaks corresponded to those reported in the existing literature [17]. After VOx loading, the diffraction pattern of ZSM-5 did not change, meaning there was no structural change in the MFI structure. Only less intensity due to the loss of crystallinity during the impregnation. This was in agreement with Liu et al., who studied vanadium/ZSM-5 for styrene oxidation; while increasing vanadium loading, the relative crystallinity decreased from 97 % to 66 % and 45 % [18]. Depending on the supports, vanadium oxide species produced after calcination will differ. At coverages of up to a monolayer, VO4 units were mainly isolated and polymerized [22,23]. In general, the oxygen bond with V5+ varies depending on the coverage on the surface; low coverage forms tetrahedral, while high coverage tends to form octahedral [24]. At medium and high vanadium loadings, crystalline V2O5 and amorphous vanadium oxide are produced [18,25,26]. VOx peak and crystalline V2O5 were not identified in the XRD spectra in all three catalysts (H-ZSM-5, VOx/ZSM-5, and VOx/SiO2-ZSM-5), indicating a well-dispersed VOx phase and amorphous isolated and polymerized VOx species [2]. This result aligns with the result studied by Amusa et al. and Al-Ghamdi et al., where VOx was impregnated in γ-Al2O3 support. The existence of an amorphous phase of polymeric vanadium species covering a monolayer surface is most likely responsible for producing highly distributed VOx phases [21]. While in VOx/Al2O3-ZSM-5 catalyst, crystalline V2O5 phase was present in the XRD results in 2θ at 30° and 52°. This result was in agreement with Yu et al., who studied VOx/γ-Al2O3 for Catalytic destruction of PCDD/Fs that VOx above 7 % loading, microcrystalline V2O5 will appear in the XRD spectra attributed to the formation of crystalline phase V2O5 particles [27]. VOx/SiO2-ZSM-5 catalysts show the least relative crystallinity than other catalysts due to the amorphous phase of SiO2, which makes the crystallinity of the mixture SiO2 and ZSM-5 less. The peaks at 37°, 45°, and 67° are ascribed to γ-Al2O3 [28]. However, since the intensity of the identity peak of γ-Al2O3 is less than H-ZSM-5, the identity peak of γ-Al2O3 in the composite is slightly visible. 3.2 Morphology and elemental mapping Scanning electron microscopic (SEM) images provide information about the morphology of the synthesized catalyst, as shown in Fig. 4. VOx/ZSM-5 exhibited morphology with well-defined grained nanoparticles and curved crystals with relatively uniform size and shape. SEM images of the VOx/ZSM-5 and VOx/SiO2-ZSM-5 samples showed that the deposition of vanadium particles formed a dense layer over the zeolite surface. This result was in line with Liu et al., who studied vanadium in ZSM-5 for styrene oxidation, which has irregular small particles after adding vanadium [18]. These results complemented BET analysis and supported the confirmation of mesopores in the zeolites sample). EDX mapping micrographs are illustrated in Fig. 4 below, which confirms that vanadium is dispersed uniformly over the support surface in both catalysts. 3.3 BET surface area and textural properties Table 1 and Fig. 5 exhibit the results of nitrogen gas adsorption and desorption tests, including determining BET surface area, pore volume, and average pore size using the BJH technique. Adsorption and desorption isotherms of all samples are shown in Fig. 5 , exhibit type IV isotherm according to classification by IUPAC, which indicates mesopore materials. The samples ZSM-5(50) and VOx/ZSM-5 from P/P0 = 0.47–1 exhibit a hysteresis loop and have an H4-type hysteresis loop which indicates a slit-shaped pore. Meanwhile, VOx/SiO2-ZSM-5 shows a narrow range hysteresis loop from P/P0 = 0.75–1 and has an H3-type hysteresis loop indicating a wedge-shaped pore. Samples VOx/Al2O3-ZSM-5 have an H1-type hysteresis loop from P/P0= 0.8–1, showing cylindrical pore-type materials. The textural properties and chemical composition of the Zeolite samples are presented in Table 1. As shown in Table 1, the BET surface area and the total pore volume decreased from 394 m2/g and 0.22 cm3/g to 308 m2/g and 0.18 cm3/g, respectively, with the addition of VOx to ZSM-5. The addition of VOx with different supports increases the pore size of the catalyst and makes it mesopores, as shown in Fig. 5. Mesopores of the catalyst were contributed from SiO2 and Al2O3 mixed with H-ZSM-5. Furthermore, mesoporous SiO2 is regarded as promising catalyst support for selective oxidation of light alkanes due to its relative inertness and accessible nanoporous space, encouraging quick desorption of partially oxidized products to prevent deep oxidation [29,30]. The elemental metal composition was estimated by X-ray fluorescence (XRF). XRF results are also shown in Table 1. The vanadium loading in the support was consistent with the calculation during the synthesis, around 10 % of vanadium. After the vanadium loading, the silica-to-alumina ratio also agreed with the parents' ZSM-5, which is 50. 3.4 Reducibility of the catalyst Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) tests provided insights into the reducibility of surface VOx species. The literature shows that TPR patterns are substantially dependent on VOx surface coverage. At low vanadium loading, the precursor's interaction with the support's surface hydroxyl groups resulted in the preferred formation of tetrahedral vanadium species. With increased vanadium loading, the tiny clusters might polymerize into larger structures. Eventually, increasing vanadium loading resulted in the production of V2O5 crystallites, as demonstrated by XRD [31,32]. The Vanadium oxide with different support TPR profiles can be seen on Fig. 6. The reduction with H2 was accomplished in the temperature range of 250–700°C. The support influences the TPR profile, which indicates different oxide forms. The sample VOx/Al2O3-ZSM-5 showed a broad peak with a reach of 470 οC at maximum, which means one reduction step from V2O5 to V2O3, confirming V2O5 presence in the XRD result. This result agreed with El-Badawi et al., who studied the VOx/Al2O3-ZrO2 catalyst for ODH of ethane reaction [33]. A broad peak at a higher temperature at 550 οC was seen for the sample of VOx/SiO2-ZSM-5 in the spectra, which indicates strong interaction and well-dispersed vanadium in SiO2 support due to the high surface area of SiO2. The same TPR profile was reported by Ying et al. when loading Vanadium to SBA-15 for oxidative dehydrogenation of propane [34]. Sample VOx/ZSM-5 showed two reduction peaks at 510°C assigned for the VOx bond with Alumina in ZSM-5 and 610 °C for the VOx bond with silica in ZSM-5. There is a shift to higher temperatures when VOx is reduced at the surface of ZSM-5 due to the well-dispersed and strong interaction of vanadium in the ZSM-5 catalyst. 3.5 Catalyst structure The Raman spectra of every catalyst are shown in Fig. S2 (a). All samples had spectra dominated by the V2O5 phase, with only the highest intensity VOx phase peaks (∼165, 845, 881, and 934 cm−1) remaining detectable in the VOx/SiO2-ZSM-5 catalyst. This suggests that most of the initial VOx has changed to V2O5. This outcome supports the XRD and XPS analyses, which show that most of the vanadium at the surface catalyst is in the form of V2O5, except for VOx/SiO2-ZSM-5, where a small amount of vanadium is still in the form of VOx polyvanadate because it has a large surface area. This result agreed with Ferran et al., who studied vanadium oxide thin film on SiO2 and Al2O3 using Raman and XPS with different temperature oxidation. Most of the vanadium is in V2O5 form [35]. Fig. S2 (b) shows V2p3/2, the binding energies of all catalysts. The deconvolution of the V2p3/2 line yields three Binding energy locations at 516.6 eV, 516.8 eV and 518 eV, respectively, attributed to the V3+, V4+ and V5+ species [36]. Table S1 lists vanadium species' relative concentration and oxidation state determined by V2p3/2 peak-fitting from the XPS spectra. There are V5+, V4+, and V3+ species on the catalysts, and it is evident that the V4+ species is more on the VOx/SiO2-ZSM-5 catalyst than on the other samples due to the high surface area. Hence, the vanadium oxide present on the surface is monomeric or polyvanadate. The vanadium oxidation state in the VOx/Al2O3-ZSM-5 sample is almost pure in the V5+ state, which means all the vanadium in the V2O5 crystalline structure. The redox cycles of V5+/V4+ are thought to have contributed to the oxidation process by causing the creation of V4+ and V5+ species. The V4+ species can produce more oxygen vacancies, which enhances the oxygen's mobility and the catalysts' capacity for redox for oxidative dehydrogenation [37]. 3.6 Acidity and acid type analysis The NH3-TPD profile for all the catalysts is provided in Fig. 7 (a). The ZSM-5 catalyst shows a typical TPD profile for zeolites, showing two desorption peaks at high and low temperatures, representing strong and weak acidity. The quantity of acidity is presented in Table 2. The VOx/ZSM-5 sample depicts the strong acidity peak shift to lower temperatures and decreased intensity, probably because vanadium oxide covered the Brønsted acid sites after the impregnation. The weak acidity peak at low temperatures was related to Lewis’s acid sites, which were increased caused by dispersed vanadium oxide or extra-framework aluminum sites. This result agreed with Possato et al., who studied Mo and V oxide supported on ZSM-5 for oxy dehydration of glycerol reaction [38] The VOx/Al2O3-ZSM-5 samples showed the same behavior. Still, this sample showed severe dealumination after impregnation and heat treatment. The NH3-TPD profile for the prepared support before the mixing is provided in Fig. S3. VOx/SiO2 has weak acidity due to the vanadium oxide loading, and VOx/Al2O3 has higher acidity than VOx/SiO2 due to the γ-Al2O3 support. Pyridine infrared spectroscopy was used to examine the Lewis and Brønsted acid sites in ZSM-5 and demonstrated in Fig. 7 (b) All zeolites exhibit clear absorption bands at 1545, 1490, and 1450 cm−1. Pyridine adsorption on Brønsted acid sites occurs on the absorption band at 1545 cm−1 [29]. The absorption peak at 1450 cm−1 is caused by pyridine adsorption on Lewis’s acid sites in the structures. The absorption band at 1490 cm−1 indicates pyridine adsorption occurs on both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites [30]. This shows Brønsted and Lewis acids' presence on all vanadium-ZSM-5 zeolite catalysts. The quantity of the Brønsted and Lewis acids is presented in Table 2. 4 Oxidative cracking of n-hexane in fluidized bed reactor The catalytic activity of the catalysts in oxidative cracking of n-hexane was evaluated in a CREC Riser Simulator as a fluidized bed reactor. Blank tests without any catalyst were conducted to assess the role of thermal cracking at a maximum temperature of 600°C. The results showed primarily n-hexane, indicating little thermal cracking influence. Then, the catalyst was evaluated at temperatures ranging from 500 to 575 °C, with reaction times ranging from 5 to 20 s. Catalyst regeneration was done between two experiments by circulating air for 15 minutes at 600 °C. Then, the reactor was cleaned with argon to ensure there was no oxygen inside the reactor. Each experiment was done many times to confirm that product distribution is consistent. Repeated trials yielded n-hexane conversion and product selectivity within ± 3.2 % of the standard deviation. 4.1 The role of VOx in the n-hexane catalytic cracking Different ZSM-5 modified with VOx with different supports were tested for optimum catalytic activity conversion and selectivity to olefin. Fig. 8 shows catalyst samples' activity (conversion and selectivity) for n-hexane cracking under the same conditions. Conversion increasing VOx/SiO2-ZSM-5 > VOx/Al2O3-ZSM-5 > ZSM-5. After VOx/Al2O3 introduction, conversion increased from 51 % to 69 %; although the total acidity decreased, there was a contribution from the lattice oxygen from the vanadium introduction that made the conversion increase. VOx/SiO2 addition results conversion became 87 %. This might be due to increasing acidity when adding VOx and the contribution of VOx's lattice oxygen in the supports. NH3-TPD results showed strong acidity formed when adding VOx due to the V-O-Si and V-O-Al bonds. This result is in line with Hu et al., who studied the introduction of VOx/Al2O3 on n-hexane cracking over ZSM-5 catalyst, which gives a higher reaction rate and another reaction pathway that offers different product distribution than the parent catalyst [31]. Fig. 8 also shows evidence of a dehydrogenation reaction; light alkane (C2-C4) significantly dropped from 38 % to 16 % and 18 %, and the selectivity to light olefin increased from 37 % to 69 % and 56 % with the addition of VOx with different support. COx also formed after adding VOx, indicating that lattice oxygen in VOx was involved in the oxidative dehydrogenation reaction. It was found that adding VOx with different supports might cause the oxidative propane dehydrogenation reaction to convert propane to propylene, ethylene, and methane. The introduction of VOx with different supports also affects product distribution. In addition, VOx will produce less butylene and more ethylene and propylene. Al2O3 support gives the product more ethylene, while SiO2 support gives a higher amount of propylene. C 3 H 8 + V 2 O 5 → V 2 O 4 + C 3 H 6 + H 2 O C 3 H 8 + V 2 O 5 → V 2 O 4 + C 2 H 4 + CO + H 2 O 4.2 Effect of contact time and catalyst-to-weight ratio To demonstrate the effects of reaction time for VOx/SiO2-ZSM-5 catalyst, reactions were conducted at reaction temperatures 550 °C with the same catalyst-to-weight ratio and three different reaction times of 5 s, 10 s, and 15 s. Fig. 9 (a) shows the variation of n-hexane conversion, product selectivity, and yields. Expectedly, the conversion of n-hexane over VOx/SiO2-ZSM-5 increased with time. This finding is consistent with the kinetic effects study by Amusa et al., who studied the kinetics of n-hexane cracking using VOx/SrO-γ-Al2O3 catalyst using a fluidized bed reactor [21]. The selectivity and yields to olefin, especially propylene, also increased until 10 s but decreased if the time was longer. This might be attributed to the over-cracking due to the longer contact time in the zeolite. The Olefin produced was cracked in the active site of the catalyst. The optimum time for reaction is 10 s, which gives high conversion and selectivity to olefin. To get a better understanding of VOx/SiO2-ZSM-5 catalyst in n-hexane cracking reaction at temperature 550°C, different catalyst-to-weight ratios were studied by varying the volume of the feed 20 μL and 30 μL with the same weight of the catalyst inside the reactor 0.2 g of catalyst. Fig. 9 (b) shows the activity result of different catalyst ratios for the n-hexane cracking reaction. The n-hexane conversion decreased with the feed volume increased. This was understandable because the more hexane, the less contact the feed had with the catalyst—the same behavior with the selectivity to light olefin (ethylene, propylene, and butene). Selectivity and yield to olefin were higher when the catalyst-to-weight ratio was high because more feed was reacted with the catalyst, and the probability of producing olefin was high when the conversion was high. 4.3 Effect of the proximity of the active sites on catalyst activity VOx was introduced directly to the ZSM-5 to represent the closed proximity between acidity and metal oxide. The influence of VOx was evaluated on the n-hexane cracking reaction activity at 550 °C for 10 s. The closed proximity inside the fluidized bed reactors is illustrated in Fig. 10. The selectivity and conversion of the catalyst were compared. The n-hexane conversion and selectivity are shown in Fig. 11; we can see that the activity for both catalysts is almost identical between parent H-ZSM-5 and VOx/ZSM-5. Acidity losses due to the VOx impregnation were compensated with oxidative cracking by lattice oxygen in the metal oxide. VOx addition to the ZSM-5 slightly increased selectivity to total olefins from 36.9 % to 37.4 %. The product distribution of olefin is somewhat different from the parent H-ZSM-5; this might be due to the other pathway because of metal oxide. Vanadium oxide provided dehydrogenation of the active site. It promoted the oxidative dehydrogenation reaction of the n-hexane to hexene, followed by cracking in the acid site of the ZSM-5, giving different product distributions. This result was in line with adding other transition metals like Fe [32], Cr [39], and Co[40], Which promote the dehydrogenation reaction for the light alkane byproduct. The position and proximity of the metal oxide and acid sites determine the reaction mechanism and product distribution. 4.4 Proposed reaction mechanism It is widely believed that the cracking of naphtha using zeolite as a catalyst follows the bimolecular or classical mechanism, which includes the generation of carbenium ions as an initiation stage and then the propagation and termination stage. In contrast, the monomolecular mechanism, the catalytic paraffin cracking process, involves the generation of non-classical pentacoordinate carbonium ions over strong Brönsted acid sites through the protolysis of a C-H or C-C bond. These ions decompose to lower paraffin, a larger carbenium ion, or hydrogen. Zeolite characteristics, reaction conditions, type of hydrocarbon, and other variables influence the predominance of one or both in paraffin catalytic cracking [41,42]. Based on the reaction results, Fig. 12 (a) depicts a hypothetical n-hexane reaction mechanism over a tandem ZSM-5 catalyst. When olefin conversion and concentration were low in the early stages of the reaction, the monomolecular protolytic cracking mechanism predominated. The carbenium ions produced by the breakdown of the pentacoordinate carbonium ions might then undergo a hydride transfer reaction to generate a C6H13 + carbenium ion with an n-hexane molecule, which could be vital in the reaction chain. The monomolecular cracking route's function diminished as the reaction continued, and the bimolecular mechanism grew more dominant. Light alkane byproduct produced from the cracking will react with the metal oxide active site to produce alkene and water. According to the previous study by Hu et al., introducing VOx/support could change the reaction mechanism of n-hexane cracking [31]. The lattice oxygen species from VOx/support were the active species for light alkane dehydrogenation reaction and, hence, responsible for catalytic activity improvement. The reaction data showed an improved conversion and product distribution from VOx/support introduction. The introduction of VOx/support offered different mechanisms for initiating the conversion of n-hexane. Combining the data and results, Fig. 12 (b) depicts a reaction pathway for n-hexane conversion over mixed VOx/support and a ZSM-5 catalyst. The n-hexane is activated, forming n-hexene as an intermediate species by lattice oxygen from vanadium; then, it was cracked in the Brönsted acid site, producing some H2O and olefins. A carbenium ion was formed when the Brönsted acid site interacted with the olefin product, which may transfer a hydride, creating a new carbenium ion to an n-hexane molecule. The cracking reaction route might follow the classical mechanism, and further reaction processes could occur, such as cracking, isomerization, cyclization, and dehydrogenation. This mechanism might happen if the feed reaches the metal oxide active site and then the acid site in the zeolite. 4.5 Stability test A stability test of n-hexane cracking for VOx/SiO2-ZSM-5 catalyst was examined in a fixed-bed reactor at 550 °C with WHSV 5 h−1 for 12 hours. The time on stream (TOS) results figure is shown on Fig. S3. Conversion of n-hexane starts from 58 % at the beginning of the reaction and then decreases to 37 % within 12 h TOS due to the carbon formation inside the zeolite that blocked the acid site. Carbon formation in the zeolite happened due to the formation of heavier hydrocarbon or BTX that cannot desorb from the pore of the ZSM-5 [43]. The same result was shown by Urata et al. while studying coke location on ZSM-5 in n-Hexane cracking that coke reaction blocked the micropores inside the zeolite and then grew to the surface of the ZSM-5 sample [44]. The Olefin selectivity is almost stable, around 60 % within the operation time. This indicates that the carbon formed only inside the pore of the ZSM deactivates the acid site and not in the metal oxide at the surface. 4.6 Coke Analysis Various forms of carbon deposits on the surface of catalysts are frequently detected in many processes, including n-hexane catalytic cracking. Carbon deposits in catalysts may often be easily recognized using X-ray diffraction, SEM, TGA, and Raman spectroscopy. Surface morphology and particle structure characterization were analyzed for VOx/SiO2-ZSM-5 catalyst for fresh and spent catalyst using SEM, as shown in Fig. S4 . It can be seen from Fig. S4 that the spent catalyst had accumulation, and the blocked pores present were because of the coke formation, which caused the deactivation of the zeolite. It is also confirmed from the EDS and EDX mapping that carbon is present in the spent catalyst. TGA and Raman did a coke analysis from a spent catalyst to understand the carbon formed in the catalyst after the reaction. The TGA of the spent catalyst was performed to measure the amount of coke deposited. Raman's analysis investigated the type of carbon formed on the spent catalyst. Fig. 13 shows the results of this investigation. Coke deposition on catalysts is essential to catalyst deactivation during cracking. This deposition reduces the number of active acid sites, which slows down the process. Several parameters determine the coke quantity accumulated at the catalyst, including catalytic reactivity, strong acid sites, acid site density, and catalyst morphology and design. It is evident from the TGA graph in Fig. 13 (a) that weight loss due to the carbon is 4 %. This result was better than Urata et al., which studied coke deposit in n-hexane cracking reaction over ZSM-5 with varying crystal sizes, which gave the amount of coke 20 % for TOS 12 h [44]. Lattice oxygen in the vanadium prevents coke formation in the zeolite catalyst. Weight loss from 50 to 150 °C is attributed to the moisture content in the catalyst. The weight lost from 350 to 650 °C due to the coke in the spent catalyst. There are two types of carbon in the spent catalyst, indicated in the two peaks at 375 °C and 600 °C, which are assigned as amorphous and graphitic carbon, respectively. Raman spectra shown in Fig. 13 (b) exhibited three prominent peaks: the G band of 1620 cm−1, the G’ band of 2700 cm−1 corresponds to the graphitic carbon, and the D band of 1357 cm−1 corresponds to the amorphous carbon. 4.7 Result comparison with other references The performance of n-hexane cracking over ZSM-5-based catalysts in some references and from this work is shown in Table 3. Different silica-to-aluminum ratios were studied by Langaroudi et al.; a higher silica-to-aluminum ratio will decrease the conversion but increase selectivity to olefin [45]. Adding metal to the ZSM-5 increases the catalyst's performance; Li et al. study showed ZSM-5 monolith catalysts that were 3D printed and doped with Cr, Cu, and Ni showed excellent selectivity for benzene, toluene, and xylene (BTX). Still, the light olefins selectivity was enhanced by doping the ZSM-5 monolith with Y [46]. Lawson et al. studied the incorporation of 15 % of Zirconia, vanadium, and chromium into the ZSM-5 catalyst. The chromium-doped monolith provided the maximum selectivity toward different olefins, 85 % n-hexane conversion, no deactivation after six hours, and 0 % BTX formation [47]. VOx/SiO2-ZSM-5 catalyst in this work has better activity than other catalysts in conversion and especially selectivity to olefin. 5 Conclusion Catalytic cracking of n-hexane was investigated in a fluidized bed reactor at temperature 550 °C and atmospheric pressure using tandem catalyst vanadium oxide and ZSM-5. Vanadium oxide with different supports and proximity was introduced to the acid catalyst ZSM-5, and its influence on activity and product distribution was studied. Vanadium oxide could alter the acidity of the zeolite and available lattice oxygen for tandem reaction. It was found that adding vanadium as a tandem catalyst with ZSM-5 changed the initial n-hexane cracking conversion, which increased from 51 % to 69.1 % for VOx/Al2O3 addition and became 86.7 % for VOx/SiO2 addition. The product distribution, especially selectivity to light olefin, was significantly changed due to the oxidative dehydrogenation reaction of light alkane in the vanadium active site. Light alkane (C2-C4) significantly dropped from 38 % to 16–18 % with the addition of VOx with different support. The optimum time for reaction is 10 s, which gives high conversion and selectivity to olefin and prevents an over-cracking reaction. Closed proximity tandem catalyst VOx/ZSM-5 gives different product selectivity than parent ZSM-5 due to the other pathway, which promotes dehydrogenation reaction. This study has limitations on how to put the vanadium oxide active site location inside the pore of the ZSM-5. Tandem catalysts must have a suitable structure, proximity, metal location, and acidity to improve light olefin selectivity. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic cracking of naphtha to produce olefins using ZSM-5 can fulfill the growing demand for light olefins and the energy problem. In the current work, vanadium oxide in different supports was mixed with ZSM-5 as a tandem catalyst for oxidative cracking of n-hexane to light olefins. The results showed that adding vanadium as a tandem catalyst with ZSM-5 increased n-hexane conversion to 68.8 % for VOx/Al2O3 and 86.7 % for VOx/SiO2 addition. Selectivity to light olefin was significantly changed due to the oxidative dehydrogenation reaction in the vanadium active site. The position and proximity of the metal oxide and acid sites determine the reaction pathway and product distribution. A stability test showed that the conversion of n-hexane decreased from 58 % to 37 %. Still, the selectivity to olefin was stable at 60 % due to the carbon formation blocking the acid site, not the metal oxide sites.
